div.div:
Dash is a service of the University of California Curation Center of the California Digital Library.
Copyright © 2014 The Regents of the University of California

Dash is a collaborative project between the
UC Libraries and the UC Curation Center.

div.p: Dash is currently a service for UC-affiliated researchers. Not all campuses have adopted or implemented Dash yet. Check your campus status on the Dash GitHub wiki. Once a campus has adopted and configured Dash, researchers from that campus can use Dash to archive and share research data sets (subject to access restrictions set at the campus level).
div.h2: What if I have collaborators outside of the UC?
div.p: You will need UC campus-issued credentials (username and password) for a partner campus to log into the system and deposit data. You can, however, add your collaborators to the “data contributors” section of the metadata. Although only researchers from a partner campus (logged in with the appropriate credentials) can deposit data, anyone can search, view and download datasets in Dash.

Data submitted to Dash is released under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution license (CC-BY-4.0). This means anyone can access the datasets, download them, and use them provided they give proper attribution. Although many researchers would prefer to maintain more control over who downloads and uses their data, we believe that having data that are fully open is the best way to enable academic advancement. Read the Panton Principles for Open Data in Science for more information. For more information on why Dash requires CC-BY, see our Policies.
div.h2: Do you support data embargoes or restricted access?
div.p: Not at this time. We do, however, have plans to expand the Dash functionality to include both features. If you have specific requests for other functional enhancements, please add them to our Dash GitHub Issue Tracker.
div.h2: What do I need to submit the data?

ul.li: Appropriate credentials issued by a UC partner campus
Information about the dataset, including title, creators, keywords, an abstract, and contact information
Access to files comprising the data set

div.h2: Are there any file format requirements?
div.p: No. Files of any type are acceptable for deposit. Ideally, file types should be non-proprietary and conform to recognized disciplinary standards or best practices. If you have files of a specialized or proprietary nature, be sure they are accompanied by any pertinent information that would allow the proper viewing and/or usage of the file. This information could be stored in the "Methods" section of the metadata, or as a separate "Readme" document archived alongside the data set files.
div.h2: What best practices can I follow for data preparation?
div.p: There are a variety of best practices depending on your field of research. For generic help, see the DataONE Primer on Data Management Best Practices (PDF). Generally,

ul.li: Ensure data files are the most up-to-date and complete versions
Ensure the integrity of data files (check if corrupted)
Ensure that all data relating to human subjects has been properly de-identified
Double-check the accuracy of the descriptive metadata
Enter as much descriptive metadata as possible in the indexing fields
Ensure that any information critical to the proper viewing and/or usage of the data is included in the submission (e.g., as a separate 'Readme' file)

div.h2: For how long will the data be available?
div.p: Once you have deposited data, it is permanently archived and available through the California Digital Library’s Merritt Repository. See our Policies for more information.
div.h2: How will someone find my data?
div.p: Metadata will be indexed by the Thomson-Reuters Data Citation Index and Scopus. All datasets in Dash are given a unique Digital Object Identifier or DOI. Entering the DOI URL in any browser will take the user to the dataset’s landing page in Dash. Dash also provides a faceted search and browse capability for direct discovery.
div.h2: Do the data have to be associated with a publication?
div.p: No. Dash accepts all high quality data, regardless of whether it’s been used to publish a paper.
div.h2: Do I need to log into Dash to get data?
div.p: Persons requesting data are not required to sign in in order to do so.
div.h2: Do I have to pay for data?
div.p: No, currently these data are made publicly available free of charge.
div.h2: What if I have questions about the data?
div.p: Please contact the dataset creator, whose information is provided as part of the dataset metadata. You can also contact us at uc3@ucop.edu.

about.p: Dash is a new, easy-to-use solution for the effective curation of and access to campus research data. It is designed to be a simple self-service curation tool for researchers to archive and share their datasets.

ul.li: Prepare data for curation by reviewing best practice guidance for the creation or acquisition of digital research data.
Select data for curation through local file browse or drag-and-drop operation.
Describe data in terms of the DataCite metadata schema.
Identify data with a persistent DOI for permanent citation and discovery.
Preserve, Manage, and Share data by uploading to a public Merritt collection.
Discover and retrieve data through faceted search and browse.

about.p: See our Frequently Asked Questions and Policies pages for more information. Dash is an ongoing project; for updates and information on how to participate, see our GitHub site.

Data sharing is critical for the advancement of scientific knowledge. Researchers benefit from increased collaborations, validation, and recognition of their work; institutions and funders benefit from the measurable increase in the impact of their resources and investments; and society benefits from the faster pace at which science can progress and an increased confidence in the integrity of the scientific enterprise. There are several barriers to providing access to data, and currently data sharing is mostly done by large, well funded multi-investigator projects. If these barriers were addressed, allowing individual investigators to share their primary research data quickly and easily, we could create a new culture of transparency and efficiency—likely resulting in major positive impacts on scientific advancement.
UC Dash is a collaborative project between the UC Libraries and the UC Curation Center (UC3) at the California Digital Library.

promo-quote.p: "Making data transparent and available is going to accelerate all of science. It's a relatively inexpensive way to get more value out of all of the work that we do." —Dr. Michael Weiner, UCSF
